Title: the adhesive duck deficiency

Scene: The camp site. Raj is telling a ghost story with the torch on his face.
Howard: How much time do we have?
Anything yet?
Hang on, how about now?
Ooh, Real Sex.
Alright, let’s see what’s on the east coast feed.
Oh, this sucks, I’m switching back to Real Sex.
Okay, the best I can tell, there are eight other campsites nearby. Mostly science nerds like us, but just over yon ridge are two not unattractive middle school teachers who reek of desperation.
Oh I don’t know, 50, 55.
I am.
Look, they gave me homemade cookies.
Relax, I said we’d stop by a little later after they have their nap.
Cookie?
Not much to tell. They had a VW Microbus and were wearing tie-dyed Grateful Dead shirts.
Up above the world so high, like little diamonds in the sky.
So, when do the meteors get here?
Stars are pretty, aren’t they?
I lost my virginity to my cousin Jeanie.
It was my Uncle Murray’s funeral. We were all back at my Aunt Barbara’s house. Our eyes locked over the pickled herring. We never meant for it to happen.
To this day, I can’t look at pickled herring without being aroused and ashamed. Oh, cousin Jeanie.
Anything?
No! What about Slim Jims?
Wait. Wait, wait. So you’re saying we’re out of food?
Me too. Check and see if we have any more pudding.
Okay, our objective is the boy scout campsite to the east. Easy target. Big doughy scout master, couple of cubs, most webelos.
Hot dogs, buns, s’mores, I mean, it’s a freaking 7-11.
Oh, my god, could it be? Yes! My mother put an I love you brisket in my backpack.
You don’t need forks. It’s so tender, it falls apart in your hands.
Maybe a tupperware bowl of roasted potatoes and carrots?
That’s still not funny.
And she was my second cousin.
You’re a real douche.
Leonard: Uh, t-minus five hours, 37 minutes to onset of meteor shower.
Uh, we have a signal, but there’s no frame lock.
Oh, hey. Dune.
Too bad Sheldon couldn’t come with us.
I wish Penny didn’t have to work, she loves camping.
Come on, you guys can’t be that hard up.
Of course, they did. That’s what grandmothers do.
Mmmm, not bad.
Stars are pretty, aren’t they?
I can feel it. I can feel the earth moving. It’s moving too fast. Raj, slow it down.
Better. Thanks.
What’s so funny?
I hate my name. It has nerd in it. Len nerd.
You know what’s a cool name? Angelo. That has angel and jell-o in it.
People could call me Angie. Yo, Angie, how’s it goin’?
No. That was the last pudding cup.
That’s what he used to eat his pudding, remember?
The only thing in here are blue ice packs.
Oh, god, I am so hungry.
Okay.
Will you shut up? We’re all hungry.
What kind of score are we looking at?
All right, everyone grab flashlights.
Quick, get forks.
I feel like we’re forgetting something important.
Raj: Okay, our position is 34.48 degrees north, 118.31 west. That means the azimuth should be 168.22 degrees relative to magnetic north with an elevation of 49.93.
We did it. We have the west coast feed of HBO.
Big deal. Every time I watch that show it’s old women putting condoms on cucumbers.
Not a great movie, but look at that beautiful desert.
Yes, it’s not the same without him. (They all laugh)
Yeah, that would have been great. You and Penny having sex in the tent while I sit out here and watch Howard hump a cactus.
Wow. Wonderful. How old are they?
Oh, menopause, nature’s birth control.
Yeah, me, too.
So, what are we waiting for?
Good idea. They’ll be refreshed.
Yeah, thank you. Mmmm.
Yeah, very tasty. Well, so tell me more about these teachers.
Huh. Mmm. Good cookies.
That’s beautiful, dude. You should… You should write that down before someone steals it.
The meteors don’t get here, the earth is moving into their path.
Okay, how’s that?
It’s your American accent. Everything you say sounds stupid. (With an American accent) Stars are pretty, aren’t they?
If I could speak the language of rabbits, they would be amazed, and I would be their king.
I would be kind to my rabbit subjects. At first.
One day, I hold a great ball for the President of France, but the rabbits, they hate me and don’t come. I am embarrassed, so I eat all the lettuce in the world and make them watch.
Right! That was so good! Sweety and meaty at the same time.
I know they’re poison, but they look like big, yummy otter pops.
Oh, I’m so hungry!
He’s right.
Me, too. But what? (Behind them, the meteor shower has begun)
…And the next morning when he woke up, he rolled over and realized… duh-duh-duh! …she was his cousin.
Who cares? You slept with your cousin.
Sheldon: Sheldon’s log, stardate 63345.3. While my colleagues are off observing the Leonid meteor shower, I have remained behind to complete my paper on the decays of highly excited massive string states. Although my research is going well I do miss the warmth of human companionship. (He laughs)

And good evening to you, Siam Palace. This is Sheldon Cooper. Yeah, I’m going to be dining alone this evening, so I’ll be reducing my usual order. I’d like to start with one quarter of the assorted appetizers plate and, uh, one half of the golden treasure for two. Oh, for heaven’s sake, in the mid-18th century, King Rama IV of Siam divided a huge empire amongst the colonial powers of Europe in order to preserve his throne. Surely, you, his cultural descendant, can handle pad thai and dumplings.

I need to go, but you keep in mind that my sharply worded comments on yelp.com recently took down a local muffin store. (At Penny’s door, knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny..
Penny?
(At Penny’s bedroom door, knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny..
Shall I come back at a better time?
Hello.
Not surprising. You have no safety mat or adhesive stickers to allow for purchase on a surface with a low coefficient of static friction.
Tubs are slippery.
I have a series of whimsical duck stickers on the bottom of my tub.
They’re holding umbrellas.
The ducks in my tub.
They’re whimsical because ducks have neither the need for, nor the ability to use umbrellas.
Well, assuming you’re correct that your right humerus is no longer seated in the glenoid socket, I would certainly think so.
I don’t drive.
Well, it seems we’ve reached an impasse.
But I could call you a cab or an ambulance.
All right. Let it never be said that Sheldon Lee Cooper ignored the pleas of a damsel in distress.
Well, it does seem rather ironic that for want of 99-cent adhesive ducks, we both might die in a fiery car crash.
I see no organizational system in here whatsoever. Which panties do you wear on Mondays?
My mother always told me one should wear clean underpants in case one is in an accident.
That doesn’t mean one won’t be in another, especially if I’m driving.
Okay, here.
All right.
We should have you checked for a concussion.
All right.
Don’t look?

Oh. Well, that’s understandable. You may be interested to know that a prohibition against looking is well established in heroic mythology. Uh, Lot and his wife, Perseus and Medusa, Orpheus and Eurydice.
They always look. It never ends well.
Ok.
It doesn’t feel like an arm.
All righty.
For the record, I should let you know this is my first time driving an actual motor vehicle.
Yes, and I have logged a considerable number of hours on a simulator.
Didn’t work out well.

One moment. According to my driver’s ed book, a side mirror is properly adjusted when a portion of the is driver’s door handle is visible in the lower right corner. There’s the handle. Oh, no, too far, bringing it back. Optimized. Now, where is the switch to adjust the passenger side mirror?
Where is the passenger side mirror?
Yes. As soon as I adjust my seat. Whee! Oh, dear. I’m going to have to start again.
Oh, I think we’re going sufficiently fast. What’s that?
That can’t be nothing, the check engine light is on. We need to find a service station.
All the more reason to consult with a mechanic before it explodes.
Mr. Spock did not pilot the Enterprise. He was the science officer, and I guarantee you that if he ever saw the Enterprise’s check engine light blinking, he would pull the ship over immediately.
Oh, oh, red light, release accelerator and slowly apply the brake. Nailed it. While we have a moment, may I ask you a question?
Why do you have the Chinese character for soup tattooed on your right buttock?
No, it isn’t. But I suppose it does take courage to demonstrate that kind of commitment to soup.
Sorry. As I told you, the hero always peeks.

All right, there’s no need to bark at me. According to the inexplicably irritable nurse behind the desk, you’ll be seen after the man who claims to be having a heart attack, but appears to be well enough to play Doodle Jump on his iPhone. We have to fill these out. Describe illness or injury.
All right. And how did the accident occur?
Cause of accident, lack of adhesive ducks. Okay, medical history. Have you ever been diagnosed with diabetes?
Kidney disease?
Migraines?
Are you currently pregnant?
Are you sure? You look a bit puffy.
When was your last menstrual period?
I’ll put, in progress. Okay, moving to psychiatric disorders, list all major behavioural diagnoses, e.g. depression, anxiety, etcetera.
Episodes of sub psychotic rage.
Possible Tourette’s. All right, moles, lesions or other skin conditions. Soup tattoo on right buttock.
I’m sorry. There, there. Everything’s going to be fine. Sheldon’s here.
Now remember, you were given powerful pain medication and a muscle relaxer, so, uh, don’t operate heavy machinery. Try not to choke on your own drool.
Yes. The charm of your drug addled candour knows no bounds.
That’s a fairly laboured metaphor, but I appreciate the sentiment behind it.
“Soft Kitty” is for when you’re sick. You’re not sick.
Penny: Come in! Hurry!
I’m back here.
Oh, for god’s sakes, I’m in the bathroom!
Get in here! Hurry! Don’t you dare knock.
I slipped in the shower, and I think I dislocated my shoulder.
What?
I know. I slipped.
Yeah, okay, whatever. Will you just turn the water off and help me up?
What?
Uh-huh.
Oh, my god. I got to go to the emergency room.
Okay, can you drive me?
Well, I can’t drive!
Ow.
No, no, no, I can’t wait that long, you got to help me, please.
No one’s saying that. Let’s go.
I don’t need panties, I just need shorts and a shirt.
One was already in an accident.
Clothes, Sheldon. I need clothes!
Seriously? Those shorts with that top?
No… No… Oh, that’s cute.
Okay, now, you got to help me put these on.
But don’t look.
I don’t want you to see me naked.
Yeah, great.
Ok, now you gotta help me get my arm into the sleeve.
Is that my arm?
Then, maybe you should let it go.
You have your learner’s permit, right?
Good.
All right, can we please go?
It’s right there.
In a parking lot in Hollywood. Now, can we please go?
Could you please drive a little faster?
Nothing. The engine does that sometimes.
No. The light has been on since I bought the car.
It’s not going to explode, just keep driving. Warp speed ahead, Mr. Spock.
Oh, god, I’m gonna lose the arm.
What?
It’s not soup, it’s courage.
How did you see it? You said you wouldn’t look.
I dislocated my shoulder.
You ready know that.
No.
No.
Getting one.
No.
Change migraine to yes.
Oh, next question.
Oh, my god, what the hell does this have to do with my stupid shoulder?
Ass.
Hey, Sheldon, Sheldon, look, I am scared and in a lot of pain. Could you please just take a break from being you for just a minute and try being, I don’t know, comforting?
Thanks. That’s much better.
Wait. You have to help me get into bed. Sheldon has to get me into bed. Bet you never thought I’d say that.

You know, people think you’re this weird robot man who’s so annoying all the time, and you totally are, but then it’s like that movie Wall-E at the end. You’re so full of love, and you can save a plant and get fat people out of the floaty chairs.
Sing “Soft Kitty” to me.
Injured and drugged is a kind of sick.

Wait, wait. Let’s sing it as a round. I’ll start. Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur… See that’s where you come in. I’ll start over. Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur… I’ve got all night, Sheldon. Soft kitty, warm kitty… (Sheldon joins in with the round) little ball of fur, happy kitty, sleepy kitty, purr, purr, purr.
Sheldon (singing): Soft kitty, warm kitty, little ball of fur…
Raj (imitating him): And she was my second cousin.

Oh, I think we’re going sufficiently fast. What’s that?
Nothing. The engine does that sometimes.

No. The light has been on since I bought the car.
All the more reason to consult with a mechanic before it explodes.
It’s not going to explode, just keep driving. Warp speed ahead, Mr. Spock.
Mr. Spock did not pilot the Enterprise. He was the science officer, and I guarantee you that if he ever saw the Enterprise’s check engine light blinking, he would pull the ship over immediately.
